column1: Accounting is the language of business. Given that the role profile of financial managers has broadened substantially in recent years with a particular emphasis on management skills, accounting and financial management graduates from our programme more than ever need to be able to communicate the key implications of this (sometimes complicated) language to a variety of different audiences in a convincing and easy manner.

Therefore, the department of Accounting and Control offers this 1 ECTS course to provide students with the necessary tools for preparing a good presentation and communicating its key messages effectively. It is mandatory for all incoming students in accounting and financial management.

The course format will be multiple sessions with experienced coaches from the J-building and companies. To pass this course, students will need to attend the sessions. An alternative assessment format will be to prepare a presentation on a subject recorded on video

column1: The importance of Frugal Innovation has begun to thaw; people, companies and governments are exploring and grasping the importance of embedding society within business practice to achieve longer-term survivability and positive growth prospects. The question for this three day bootcamp is how you can design an inquisitive and explorative process to tackle your field assignment. It will be the first time that the groups for the field assignments will work intensively together. Therewith the bootcamp is an important stepping stone towards a more precise formulation of your field assignment and getting the experience of working in a multidisciplinary group. At the end of the course, you present your outcomes to experts in the field. This is a high-paced, innovative course that allows you to apply your skills. As such, be prepared to work fast and think creatively!

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

Apply creative problem solving methods to generate unexpected ideas
Critically assess identify the riskiest assumptions underpinning your solution
Develop a proposal to test your assumptions during your field assignment
Present and pitch their solutions to real multiple (real) stakeholders
Reflect on the experience of working in a group consisting of diverse backgrounds

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94201,2020,Preventie en bestraffing,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. TFC Fischer', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip beheerscultuur.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In dit vak zullen jullie kennis opdoen van de verschillende strafdoelen, hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende resocialiserende interventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor effectieve interventies, en kritisch te kunnen reflecteren op de waarde van effectiviteitsonderzoek van interventies. Voorts zullen jullie in dit vak leren om de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid in een historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief te plaatsen. Daarnaast kunnen jullie, na afloop van het vak, de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip beheerscultuur. Dit biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94500,2020,Pricing and Revenue Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Tsoukalas', 'prof.dr.ir. NAH Agatz']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Pricing and revenue management focuses on how a firm should set and update pricing and product availability decisions across its various selling channels in order to maximize its profitability. In this course you will learn to identify and exploit opportunities for revenue optimization in different business contexts and survey current practices in different industries. You will review the main methodologies that are used in each of these areas, understand key concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation. Within the broader area of pricing theory, the course places particular emphasis on tactical optimization of pricing and capacity allocation decisions, tackled using quantitative models of consumer behavior (e.g., captured via appropriate price-response relations), demand forecasts and market uncertainty, and the tools of constrained optimization – the two main building blocks of revenue optimization systems.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course the students will:
-    be able to identify revenue management opportunities;
-    understand the different revenue management levers and the corresponding optimization approaches;
-    understand key revenue management concepts including the interaction between supply and demand, opportunity costs, customer response, demand uncertainty and market segmentation;
-    be able to formulate and solve basic pricing and revenue management optimization problems.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94517,2020,Pricing: Creating and Capturing Value,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AM Ferecatu'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, value-based pricing, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, healthcare plans, and cell phone plans.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: -    Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, and calculate profit-maximizing prices.
-    Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value.
-    Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples and case studies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95866,2020,Primaire processen,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J de Vries', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Primaire processen omvatten de product- of diensten-voortbrengende processen, waarmee bedrijven hun geld verdienen. Activiteiten die hierbij ondersteunend zijn (informatiemanagement, financieel management, personeelsmanagement en dergelijke), worden aangeduid als secundaire processen. Primaire processen in organisaties omvatten het inkoop-, productie-, verkoop, distributie-, service- en retourverwerkingsproces. In dit college wordt ook de ontwikkeling van productieprocessen tot de primaire processen gerekend. Het geheel van aan elkaar gerelateerde activiteiten behorende tot het product- of dienstcreatie en -realisatieproces noemt men in het Engels Operations Management. Voor industriële ondernemingen omvat dit aspecten als mechanisering en automatisering inclusief de bijbehorende informatietechnologie, logistiek, maar ook capaciteitsplanning en layout. Alle functies in een onderneming - van Research tot Marketing - hebben direct of indirect relaties met de voortbrengende processen. De aandacht van het vak is zowel gericht op industriële als op diensten-voortbrengende ondernemingen.

Elke organisatie heeft primaire en secundaire processen. In de primaire processen wordt toegevoegde waarde van het product of dienst gecreëerd. In de automobielindustrie bestaan de primaire processen uit het ontwikkelen en productierijp maken van nieuwe modellen en features, het efficiënt inkopen en assembleren van ingekochte componenten, zorgen voor efficiënte aan- en afvoerlogistiek, het vinden van de juiste afzetkanalen, het collecteren, demonteren en herverwerken van auto's aan het eind van hun levensloop. Bij een bedrijf als McDonald's bestaat het primaire proces uit het ontwikkelen van nieuwe producten, het vinden van goede leveranciers (wereldwijd), aan- en afvoerlogistiek van leveranciers naar de verschillende distributiecentra, fabrieken en restaurants, het productie- en verkoopproces in het restaurant en de recycling van het afval dat overal wordt gegenereerd. Het is duidelijk dat de primaire processen van dergelijke organisaties veel verschillen vertonen. Er zijn echter ook overeenkomsten.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of natural selection, population and community ecology, biodiversity, and sustainability. Students will acquire an ""ecological literacy"" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore some of today's major ecological challenges, and the important research that is being done to address these concerns. As the course description suggests, ecology is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how the interactions between individual organisms and their environments scale up to global ecosystems, this course will provide you with a good introduction to nested complexity of the natural world.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, you will be able to:

column2: • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
• design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
• apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
• characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
• assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
• use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
• compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;

column1: Does Okun’s law hold in practice? Does the Phillips curve really exist? In this course you will learn how to perform empirical analyses to answer this kind of questions. The course is strongly build upon what you have learnt in Basic Statistics and Intermediate Statistics I and is specifically aimed at students with a major in economics.

During the course we will discuss important concepts for time series such as stationarity, unit roots and autoregressive models. Moreover, you will learn how to perform the analyses in the software program Stata.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After succesful completion of this course, you:

column2: • Understand the main concepts related to simple and multiple regression;
• Are aware of common techniques and concepts for time series analysis;
• Are able to apply ordinary least squares;
• Can perform basic analyses in Stata and are able to interpret Stata output;
• Can formulate a research question and testable research hypotheses on the basis of previous research and economic reasoning;
• Can apply statistical methods to answer a research question;
• Are able to structure and discuss the research findings through a written report.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course lays the groundwork for financial modeling in Market-and Bank-Based Financial Markets. We start by discussing sources of company financial information, how different financial statements are connected, and procedures for financial statements forecasting, accuracy assessments, and valuation. In particular, we discuss how data analytics can help in this process.

The results of such analyses are important for investors who use them in assessing the risk and return of investments in corporate credit and equity markets. In each of those two markets we derive a standard optimization representations both for individual investments as well as for portfolios. We link these representations to real-world applications such as platform (P2P) lending, asset management, robo-advising, and high-frequency trading.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1.    Know which financial statements firms report and how these inform financial markets
2.    Understand how data analytics can help to assess the accuracy of accounting information
3.    Understand the methods and data issues involved in forecasting financial statements and estimating equity value
4.    Be able to apply large-scale forecasting and valuation techniques
5.    Understand the link between risk and expected returns in financial markets
6.    Understand how this is different for equity and debt markets
8.    Express investment problems as standard data learning/optimization problems
9.    Be able to apply this approach to FinTech business models</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Principles of Management will introduce you to the field of business administration and its various sub-disciplines. Business Administration is an interdisciplinary and a context-based field of study concerned with the organisation and the market environment of businesses. It is a problem-oriented discipline focusing on issues within organisations (how does an organisation set different goals and objectives?) and the interaction and relationship of the business with its surrounding (how do political factors affect the business?).

Similar to the discipline itself, this course will be context-based, using cases and examples presenting the latest business developments and current challenges business face for students to better understand the business world. Topics that will be discussed include the global context of business (business environments and business types), the business of managing, people in organisations (Human Resource Management, leadership and teams), managing information (IT), principles of marketing and finance, and political, social, economic, technological and ethical considerations affecting business. The course will provide basic knowledge on business therewith preparing you for more specialised 200 and 300 level Economics & Business major courses.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
• Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
• Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
• Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
• Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
• Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
• Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
• Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
• Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

column1: <body>De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen. De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:

column2: • Rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap)
• Overeenkomst en onrechtmatige daad als bron verbintenis
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Na het volgen en behalen van deze cursus moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht. In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht, het personen- en familierecht en het ondernemingsrecht.
• Ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
• De voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
• De verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
• De bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
• Beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
• Beoordelen of er sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en deze leerstukken kunnen toepassen.
• Het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
• De overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen.
• Zijn kennis over het personen- en familierecht in een paper aantonen.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit mastervak komen verschillende elementen uit de civielrechtelijke rechtenstudie bij elkaar. Het vak biedt mede aan de hand van actuele thema’s theoretische verdieping van het privaatrecht en bouwt tegelijkertijd voort op de vaardigheden die zijn verworven in bijvoorbeeld het mastervak Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht (eerste blok, 15 ECTS). Wat de invalshoek betreft bouwt het vak verder voort op inzichten uit andere disciplines zoals rechtseconomie en rechtspsychologie. Inhoudelijk wordt in dit vak ook aangesloten op de onderzoekslijnen die binnen de sectie burgerlijk recht in ontwikkeling zijn. De sprekers zijn eigen docenten en ook gasten van buiten de sectie en faculteit.

LET OP: de ervaring wijst uit dat u grotere kans hebt om te slagen voor dit vak (met een hoger cijfer) als u volgens het boekje studeert en dus eerst Onderzoekspracticum volgt. De omgekeerde volgorde raden we daarom af.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Verdiepende kennis verwerven van het privaatrecht, mede aan de hand van de actualiteit.
• Het leren betrekken van relevante argumenten uit andere takken van de (rechts)wetenschap  bij het analyseren en beoordelen van privaatrechtelijke wetgeving, literatuur, rechtspraak.
• Het begrijpend lezen van (Engelse) teksten over privaatrecht en de multidisciplinaire benadering van het privaatrecht.

• Het schriftelijk onder woorden kunnen brengen van argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur en het synthetiseren van de verschillende invalshoeken uit die literatuur tot een afgewogen standpunt met betrekking tot een opgegeven stelling.
• Het toepassen van de bij Onderzoekspracticum Burgerlijk Recht verworven onderzoeks- en rapportagevaardigheden

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92215,2020,Privacy, Surveillance and New Media Technologies",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SM Young'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Contemporary surveillance is a multi-directional, multifaceted and technologically-mediated phenomenon. Social media, mobile communications, sensor networks are already part of the surveillance activities of many public and private organizations. At the same time, privacy enhancing technologies and regulations as well as peer surveillance give people room for negotiation and action. In this course we will study and critically analyse these practices and associated technologies. This involves reflection on our relation to technologies and their role in our contemporary culture as well as on our understanding of surveillance and privacy and the way they are construed in different genres of media and in academic literature.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course aims to give students a broader understanding of surveillance and privacy in our technologically mediated culture. At the end of the course students can:

column2: • Understand and apply theories of privacy, surveillance, and technology to a variety of situations/contexts.
• Identify the role of new media technologies in contemporary global surveillance practices.
• Identify privacy issues in these practices and develop strategies for resilience and solutions to resolve them.
• Analyze contemporary practices of surveillance and of privacy protection.
• Present arguments defending or criticizing influential conceptualizations of surveillance.
• Integrate theoretical and practical knowledge on surveillance, privacy and new media technologies into a written paper.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94674,2020,Private Equity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['AK Grzeszczak'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. 2018 was another record year in terms of funds raised and invested into assets backed by Private Equity. As of the end of 2018, $2.5 trillion of funds globally are looking to be invested by PE funds.

This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment:
»        “Organizational” topics related to PE funds & investing;
»        Cash flow analysis & modeling (we will be using a PE/LBO model for that);

»        PE investment process (a complete cycle from a purchase idea to a completion of acquisition; and from putting the asset up for sale through to a complete exit) - we will follow a “live” (recently completed) transaction;
»        Negotiation of a Term Sheet/Letter of Intent and Share Purchase Agreement (SPA);
»        Finalization of the transaction price (Locked Box and Completion Accounts mechanisms);
»        Practical key lessons from prior transactions, i.e. practical experience;

With the exception of item 1 (above), where some theory and “informational” delivery (deliberately kept to a modest minimum) is scheduled, this course focuses on practical aspects and transaction based learning.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •    Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders.
•    Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques.

•    Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing).
•    Understand how market conditions impact the Private Equity industry: leverage & credit markets, equity market valuations.
•    Anticipate events and trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper insight of advanced corporate finance.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The PAX Moot is a young international moot competition for law students. Initially it was organised between French Universities, but in 2018 the turning point came, and the event opened its doors to students from all over the world. With each edition more teams from Europe and worldwide decide to join the PAX Moot and compete in solving an imaginary case on matters of private international law (for more information see https://paxmoot.com/).
The Erasmus School of Law (ESL) teams participated in the competition since the first international edition in 2018 and managed to secure good results with each participation.

The preparation for the competition begins with the publication of the fictional case in January each year and ends with the oral rounds that are scheduled in late May. In preparation for the pleading rounds, each team has to write and submit written memoranda for the claimants and defendants. These are due in April, after which the preparation for the oral pleadings begins. The selected ESL students will be preparing the PAX Moot from January to May.

This elective course gives students a unique opportunity to put their legal knowledge, research and advocacy skills into practice. During the course, the students will have to work on the fictional case dealing with matters of private international law, as well as some related aspects concerning EU law, international law, human rights and/or arbitration. The first months of the course will be dedicated to legal research and the development of legal argumentation in preparing the claimants and defendants memoranda. Following the submission of the written memoranda, the students will have to start pleading for the parties they are representing (claimants or defendants) in training oral rounds. This part will be completed with the pleading rounds of the PAX Moot before panels of judges composed of specialists in private international law, judges, and lawyers.

All the preparation of the PAX Moot is carried out under the careful supervision of professors and researchers of the Erasmus School of Law. Students taking this course will have the chance to test their knowledge, ideas and persuasive skills in writing and during the numerous pleading rounds organised with the trainers and lawyers at law firms. Finally, the students will have an opportunity to challenge themselves and respond to the challenges of the other participating teams when acting as councils for the claimants or the defendants in the rounds of the PAX Moot.

Both Dutch and international students registered at ESL for Master or advanced Bachelor programmes can decide to participate in the selection for the ESL PAX Moot team. From the group of applications received usually a number of four students will be selected to prepare for the PAX Moot.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• build an in-depth knowledge of private international law, with a focus on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, and applicable law in international disputes, as well as connected areas such as EU law, international law, human rights and/or arbitration;
• develop their writing skills, more specifically the drafting of memoranda and pleadings;
• develop their practical skills, including legal English proficiency;
• develop the presentation skills, especially oral advocacy skills and persuasion;
• learn to plead the (subjective) legal position of one of the parties to a case;
• learn to operate and excel in a team environment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96585,2020,Production Cultures in the Streaming Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. ML Wayne'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This is an exciting and transformative moment for streaming industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves (e.g. Netflix, Spotify, YouTube) creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main goal of this research workshop is to train students to overcome these challenges using the “production culture” approach. This approach, sometimes called media historiography, media industry studies, or trade press analysis, is grounded in the academic perspective that understands media industry discourse as centrally important to understanding media industry practice.

Students will learn how to gather and analyze relevant data about the streaming industries from a variety of publicly available secondary sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, annual reports, policy reports, and financial documents. Students will formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industry. Students will create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data. Their efforts culminate in an academic research paper.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95872,2020,Professional Development I,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Alkema', 'JJ Werkhoven, MSc', 'VL Detchev']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The rise of automation and AI causes rapid changes in our private and professional lives often outpacing peoples’ ability to adapt. The future of work therefore calls for the adoption of lifelong learning and places more and more importance on higher cognitive, social and emotional, and technological skills. It is no longer enough to simply obtain a university degree. Those who want to remain employable and successful throughout their careers and fully participate in society need to embrace a growth mindset and muster the discipline and self-motivation to constantly develop themselves and others.

In addition, our increasingly globalized world leads to higher levels of ambiguity and many of the problems managers are confronted with today and in the future are characterized by increasing complexity that require the careful consideration and evaluation of different trade-offs and stakeholders. Those who want to become agents for positive change need to understand how to navigate these complexities with integrity, how to develop political savvy and how to build communities to initiate and sustain that change.

It is evident that for future managers to be successful it is not sufficient that they are content experts and understand the intricacies of subjects such as finance, marketing and operations management. Instead, they need to be equally skillful when it comes to e.g. time- and self-management, emotional intelligence, stakeholder management and moral decision-making.

The Professional Development & Mentoring Course aims to support students in developing these skills. This requires continuous self-reflection, feedback and above all practice. Therefore, particular emphasis is put on small-scale workshops in which students will actively practice the skills taught through lectures, online modules and self-study. Throughout the course students will regularly reflect on the progress they have made and receive peer feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • be self-reliant and take responsibility for his/her study progress by setting priorities;
• work constructively in diverse teams by employing active listening, feedback and perspective taking;
• analyse a current societal issue taking into account different stakeholders;

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95321,2020,Professional Development II,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MA de Bree', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The world is demanding new leadership for an ever more complex and dynamic world. Professional Development is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and focuses on the role of the business leader. The goal of the course is to offer students information, tools and skills to better understand, engage in and change the self, the other person, the organization and the world.

Professional Development should not only include tools for understanding and influencing the environment, but also exploring and questioning the students’ own frames of reference. Professional Development is based on the principles of transformational learning which means that the course is both outside in and inside out. This makes Professional Development a rather provocative course, with much time spend on self-exploration, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems. The course points at the responsibility of the business leader to understand her or his own frames of reference as a foundation for contributing to positive change in the world.
Students are required to formulate personal learning goals right at the start of the course, which will later on serve as a point of reference for the personal essay.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Monitor the realization of several more personal learning goals by critically incorporating the results of self-reflection, peer- and tutor feedback.

• Master presentation, writing, coaching and negotiation skills to a level that allows the student to adapt application of the skills to variation in intrinsic (personal) and extrinsic (environmental) factors in a practical context.
• Critically review and transform his or her personal frame of reference.
• Explain new insights to change and apply these in their own personal, professional, and/or educational environment.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92551,2020,Professional Development Part I: Research Design,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AT Zhelyazkova', 'prof.dr. M Haverland']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This module focuses on research design. The primary goal is to enable students to design social science research in the area of international public management and policy. We will split the design process in a number of steps including research question, concept and hypothesis specification and research design. For each step we will discuss tradeoffs and relevant quality criteria, such as relevance, internal validity and external validity. This will be done through a series of lectures. Students will make a number of weekly assignments that together will cover all elements of a research proposal. Assignments will be discussed in working groups. Note that there will be one or two sessions prior to block 3, to allow you to focus your assignment on the topic of your thesis. Although most students have had a proper introduction to social science methods, they should not underestimate the difficulty of developing a relevant and rigorous research project that meets the standards of a master program.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After passing the module professional development students will be able:

column5: to develop a relevant, feasible, and rigorous research design;
to indicate the trade-offs in designing research and to defend their choices made in developing their research project;
to evaluate research in terms of relevance, specificity, measurement reliability and measurement validity, internal validity, and external validity (generalization).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92552,2020,Professional Development Part II: Preparation Labour Market,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. AG Dijkstra', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The module Professional Development focuses on the preparation for the labor market. The program is composed of:

column5: a four-days study-trip to International Organizations and Non-Governmental Organizations in Geneva. The study-trip is mandatory and involves extra costs [airfare ticket, lodging];
a one day visit to the European institutions in Brussels
a series of guest-lectures by practitioners and labor market experts to make students familiar with the and to help them to find their way at the international labor market.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94886,2020,Professional development trajectory,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['J Zhu, MSc', 'S Hofmeijer']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Professional Development Trajectory achieves two interconnected goals: to facilitate your personal development as a professional in your chosen field, and to equip you with the state-of-science methods to help others grow. Your personal development is achieved by sessions that are designed to help you a) become more aware of your values and life purpose b) clarify your strengths and weaknesses, and c) set and achieve the developmental goals that will lead you closer to your purpose.

The course also unpacks the science behind the sessions. By introducing theories of developmental psychology, we explore three fundamental questions: how individuals obtain knowledge, how employees develop their skills, and how followers grow into leaders. By learning and experiencing the science of personal development, you will be empowered to be a better trainer, coach, and mentor yourself.

This trajectory culminates in a closing session where you take stock of your own learning throughout the one year. Together with your classmates, you ready yourself for a life-long journey of personal development of yourself as well as others who will work with you.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: a) become more aware of your values and life purpose;
b) clarify your strengths and weaknesses;
c) set and achieve the developmental goals that will lead you closer to your purpose.

column1: In this course, students will have the opportunity to acquire skills necessary for employment in the professional practice of interventions and policies aimed at health behavior change. They will learn skills in evaluating their own achievement in critically reflecting on personal and professional development in the context of health psychology and behavior change. After the course students have the skills to carry out the steps of planning behavior change programs and reflect on their personal and team skills to manage such programs. The course runs in combination with the course Health Psychology and Behavior change and students will have the chance to develop skills they can apply when developing the behavior change intervention in that course.
The professional skills course addresses four topics:

column2: • Team skills: with whom do you collaborate and how?
• Managing the process of project planning: how do you organize your project and use time management or budgeting?
• Diffusion, implementation and communication: knowledge brokerage aimed at your target population such as policy makers.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will be able to...

column2: • Critically assess personal strengths and weaknesses with regard to study skills, self-management skills and team skills.
• Distinguish the stages of planning behavior change programs.
• Apply the skills and methods for , i.e. creation of a basic logic model, stakeholder analysis, activity break down, time management and budgeting.
• Critically argue the importance of accounting for diversity in target populations of interventions and policies.
• Understand theories of diffusion, dissemination and implementation.
• Create a personal portfolio consisting of the results of the tasks and assignments of the professional skills course and reflections on the completed tasks.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In dit vak draait het om advisering over strategische veranderingen in de organisatie, inrichting en besturing van de publieke sector. Hoewel verandering op het niveau van individuen en organisaties ook aan de orde komt, ligt de nadruk op veranderingen waar meerdere organisaties bij betrokken zijn (het interorganisatorische niveau). Het vak bouwt voort op onder meer Strategisch Management en Advisering (SMA) en Publiek Management Internationaal (PMI).

Het vak is als volgt vorm gegeven. De module omvat 7 weken. De eerste week staat in het teken van een inleidend college over achtergronden bij advisering over strategische veranderingen in de publieke sector. Vervolgens wordt wekelijks een thema aan de orde gesteld om theoretisch relevante concepten beter te doorgronden en dieper te doorleven. Daarbij valt te denken aan: de reorganisatie van de rijksdienst, gemeentelijke en provinciale samenwerking en fusies, maatschappelijk ondernemerschap en zelforganisatie in de publieke sector, verzelfstandiging van uitvoeringsorganisaties, professionalisering van toezicht, inspectie en controle, conflicthantering bij het organiseren in ketens, netwerken en allianties.

Het vak kent drie leerlijnen: conceptueel (abstract-theoretisch), experimenteel (concreet-casuïstisch) en reflexief (persoonlijk-biografisch). De onderwijsvorm is case-based en thema gericht. De opgedane kennis van de studenten wordt getoetst aan de hand van wekelijkse individuele en groepsopdrachten, gerelateerd aan een of meer cases passend bij de behandelde thema’s. Van de studenten wordt verlangd dat ze tijdens de collegedagen in groepen zelf aan het werk gaan en over de opbrengsten van dat werk terugkoppeling geven aan praktijkmensen die vooraf cases inbrengen.</mystyle></body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:

column5: strategische veranderingen van de publieke sector begrijpen, duiden en verklaren;
verschillende conceptuele benaderingen en strategieën van advisering over verandering onderscheiden;
de aangedragen theorie toepassen op actuele vraagstukken en concrete casuïstiek en deze analyseren op spanningen, dilemma’s en uitdagingen;
reflecteren op de theorie en de praktijk van advisering in de publieke sector;
professioneel adviseren over de aanpak van belangrijke veranderkundige vraagstukken in de publieke sector.

column1: Het vak professionele ontwikkeling bestaat uit een reeks workshops die het hele bachelorprogramma doorlopen. Het is bedoeld om studenten de vaardigheden te bieden die ze nodig hebben als verantwoordelijke managementprofessionals in de samenleving en bereidt als zodanig studenten voor op de arbeidsmarkt. Het traject omvat drie opeenvolgende jaren van training in essentiële competenties die studenten moeten beheersen om te voldoen aan de verwachtingen die managers in organisaties en de samenleving van hen verlangen. Op deze manier zijn studenten bereid om een ​​kracht te worden voor positieve verandering in de wereld door bij te dragen aan de welvaart en het welzijn van de mensen die ze beïnvloeden door hun beslissingen en acties zowel binnen als buiten de organisatie waarvoor ze werken.

Managers hebben verantwoordelijkheden die soms lastig kunnen zijn. Als vertegenwoordigers van een organisatie moeten managers zich sterk bewust zijn van de complexiteit van de omgeving waarin ze werken en van de impact die ze hebben op anderen binnen en buiten de organisatie. Om de problemen en uitdagingen aan te pakken waarmee een organisatie op elk moment in haar bestaan ​​wordt geconfronteerd, moeten professionals beschikken over sterke analytische vaardigheden en over de bereidheid en het vermogen om verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor en toezicht te houden op de consequenties van hun beslissingen voor een verscheidenheid aan betrokken stakeholders. Alleen door zo’n houding aan te nemen, kunnen managers hun 'license to operate' in de samenleving rechtvaardigen. In het onderwijsklimaat van onze school draait dit vermogen om de vier kernwaarden kritisch, creatief, zorgzaam en collaboratief. RSM-studenten zullen altijd informeren naar de grondslagen van en bewijs voor de kennis die zij toepassen in zakelijke contexten, zij zullen voortdurend streven naar creativiteit in de oplossingen die zij bedenken voor zakelijke problemen, zij zullen dit met zorg en empathie doen voor degenen die geraakt worden door hun inspanningen, en ze beseffen dat succesvolle oplossingen altijd afhankelijk zijn van constructieve samenwerking en partnerschappen met anderen. Het vak professionele ontwikkeling is erop gericht om deze waarden te gebruiken als basis voor het intellectuele en professionele onderwijs van studenten.

Het eerste jaar van dit vak richt zich in de eerste plaats op het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden in zelf- en teammanagement en communicatie- en kritisch denkvermogen, zowel voor academische als professionele doeleinden. Het vak volgt een integrale aanpak door een oefenterrein aan te bieden voor verschillende vaardigheden in nauwe afstemming met de behoeften van andere cursussen in het programma. Ondertussen worden studenten doorlopend uitgedaagd om na te denken over de fundamenten van hun rol als toekomstige managers. Vaardigheden kunnen worden beoordeeld zowel in de PO cursussen zelf als in de cursussen waarvoor de aangeboden vaardigheden vereist zijn.

Het vak professionele ontwikkeling speelt in op de specifieke behoeften van de studentenpopulatie. We zullen studenten faciliteren om hun plaats binnen ons programma te vinden en de grote verscheidenheid aan termen zoals onderwijskundige achtergronden, leefomstandigheden, etnische, sociaaleconomische, religieuze, genderoriëntatie of seksualiteit gebruiken om gezamenlijk een onderwijsomgeving te ontwikkelen waar studenten kunnen excelleren.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• hun studie effectief te organiseren, te plannen en te reflecteren en verantwoordelijkheid te nemen voor hun studievoortgang (doelen stellen, timemanagement, een actieve leerhouding aannemen, mindfulness),
• de basisprincipes en soorten interviews te begrijpen als een methode voor gegevensverzameling en ze competent toe te passen in concrete bedrijfsonderzoeksinstellingen,
• constructief te werken in teams en uitdagingen aan te pakken zoals de sustainable development goals, inclusiviteit en gemeenschapsvorming in groepsdynamiek om samenwerking te optimaliseren,
• kritisch denkvermogen te ontwikkelen en gebruiken om (academische) bronnen en andere teksten te evalueren,
• overtuigende argumenten te herkennen en te ontwikkelen en deze te gebruiken in een evenwichtig artikel of andere presentatie, door regels toe te passen met betrekking tot correcte verwijzingen,
• diverse vormen van professionele communicatie te organiseren en uit te voeren, zoals presentaties, vergaderingen en het geven en ontvangen van feedback en

• diverse opvattingen over managementprofessionaliteit te vergelijken, beoordelen en bediscussiëren met het oog op hun implementatie in de beroepspraktijk en hun impact op de samenleving in het algemeen.

column1: The world is demanding new leadership for an ever more complex and dynamic world. Professional Development is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and focuses on the role of the business leader. The goal of the course is to offer students information, tools and skills to better understand, engage in and change the self, the other person, the organization and the world.

Professional Development should not only include tools for understanding and influencing the environment, but also exploring and questioning the students’ own frames of reference. Professional Development is based on the principles of transformational learning which means that the course is both outside in and inside out. This makes Professional Development a rather provocative course, with much time spend on self-exploration, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems. The course points at the responsibility of the business leader to understand her or his own frames of reference as a foundation for contributing to positive change in the world.
Students are required to formulate personal learning goals right at the start of the course, which will later on serve as a point of reference for the personal essay.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Monitor the realization of several more personal learning goals by critically incorporating the results of self-reflection, peer- and tutor feedback.

• Master presentation, writing, coaching and negotiation skills to a level that allows the student to adapt application of the skills to variation in intrinsic (personal) and extrinsic (environmental) factors in a practical context.
• Critically review and transform his or her personal frame of reference.
• Explain new insights to change and apply these in their own personal, professional, and/or educational environment.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Het begrijpen van de basisbegrippen in objectgeoriënteerd programmeren (data hiding, interfaces, inheritance, exceptions, streams) en in staat zijn om efficiënt te programmeren met deze begrippen in Java.
• Het begrijpen van de 'programming by contract' aanpak en in staat zijn de kernconcepten (pre-and post-conditions) te programmeren voor een foutvrij middelgroot programma.
• Het begrijpen van het belang van unit testing en in staat zijn programma's te testen en te debuggen.
• In staat zijn met relevante libraries te werken.

column1: Ever done hundreds of repetitive actions on rows in tables? Ever copied daily update information from websites every day? Ever wondered how computer programs work, or how online shops keep track of all items for sale and their stock?
Then, this is the elective module for you! You will be learning the basic components of computer programs, write your own programs in Python, trace bugs and inspect variables in Jupyter Notebooks.

“Why would I want to be able to write computer programs, or tiny helpers?”, you may ask. Customized computer programs tailored to specific business are used in many companies. Being able, as a manager, to communicate with in-house or hired computer programmers is an asset.

The course comprises of exercises online in repl.it, so you can practice your skills using a web browser, with the help of programmers at RSM, together with other students and at home. The results of these exercises form part of your total grade. For the other part you will be asked to solve programming challenges in Jupyter Notebooks during an exam.

column1: •    Combine the building blocks of computer programs
•    Write, inspect and trace bugs in computer programs
•    Simplify your (repetitive) daily tasks with (little) helper programs or scripts</body>

column1: R is probably the most widely used open-source software environment for data analysis and statistical graphics in academia and business. It has its own programming language which allows not only interaction with, but also extension of its system. With over 16.000 extensions the statistical and computational toolkit is huge making the R programming language the lingua franca of data science.

In this course you will master the basics of R. You will get to know the syntax, become familiar with the major data types and learn the fundamental programming concepts. You will learn how to perform data processing and analysis tasks, and how to build visualizations and present data. You will also learn how to efficiently automate tasks that are often repeated during data analysis. Moreover, you will learn how to record your work flow and to document your results by using the R environment in combination with the R Studio IDE.
What students say about this course:

column2: • The introductory course on programming with R learned us all the relevant programming techniques and got us started to work with R. Therefore, the course was quintessential for all the other courses in the Master.
• Learning how to code in 7 weeks, what an amazing introduction for the Master!
• We started with the basics and slowly we became real programmers.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94469,2020,Programming for managers,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AAM Abdelwahed, MBA', 'dr. Y Ghiassi-Farrokhfal']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to strengthen your abilities as future managers with one of the most important yet mostly missing skills for managers: the art of programming. Managers with programming experience are able to be involved in the decision-making process of their developers. They can also --at high level-- understand whether or not each developer is performing well. In this course, we will focus on one of the most widely used programming languages: Java. This course also lays the foundation for learning other important programming languages. You should not expect to be developers in few weeks. You should rather treat this course as an intense programming tutorial for absolute beginners. It is assumed that the registered students have no previous knowledge of programming. After taking this course, you will learn how to excel in Java even further or to start learning a new programming language from scratch. Java is greatly structured to be an easy-to-learn, yet a powerful programming language.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main objective of this course is to develop comprehensive knowledge about the fundamental principles and concepts of modern computer programming. In this course, the students will gain a broad understanding of problem analysis, solution design, coding and debugging of computer programs. In particular, upon completion of the course, it is expected that you will be able to:

column2: • Translate well specified problems into pseudo-code solutions and then code them in Java
• Write small programs that allow you to accomplish useful goals
• Understand the fundamentals of the syntax and semantics of Java programming language.
• Define the necessary program structure in terms of the basic building blocks (classes, methods and properties)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92096,2020,Project: Applied Cultural Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. FJC Brouwer'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In order to get prepared to be real cultural entrepreneurs for the labor market the course is divided in three parts:
(1) Conceptual Development: development of a business plan;
(2) Realization: effectuation of the project; and

(3) Reporting and Evaluation: beyond realization, students will write a critical essay discussing “what happened?"", “what I would have done differently?"", and “what I learned from this experience?”.
The requirements for this seminar are basic knowledge about culture in general (performing or visual arts), and entrepreneurship.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this seminar is to learn from real life entrepeneurial experiences. Master students will realize an artistic production, a consultancy report or a case study with entrepreneurial aspects within three months. They will act as junior agents, performing as programmers, economists, planners, managers, marketers, auditors, fundraisers, etc. in an entrepreneurial way (with innovative elements) and with a holistic approach. They will develop competencies such as creative and critical thinking, practical (group) working skills, coordinating, collaboration, self-reflection, critical controlling, independent decision making, and performing under stress.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The different psychological assessment instruments are important tools to gather information from clients for career advice, ‘diagnosing’ clients, or for companies to hire the best candidates. By using psychological tools, which are designed to be ‘objective and standardized measures of behaviour, affect and cognition’ one can provide recommendations that have the highest likelihood of success. A score on a well-constructed test reflect an underlying psychological construct such as personality, well-being, emotional functioning, aptitude or cognitive ability.

This course deals with both the psychodiagnostic theories as well as the application of the psychological tools and instruments that could be used in different settings including but not limited to clinical and work settings.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As has been said this course is an introduction to Psychodiagnostics. After completing the course Psychodiagnostics you will have acquired:

column2: • basic knowledge of how a professional consultation is conducted following the hypothesis-testing model
• basic knowledge of personality testing, intelligence testing, neuropsychological testing and anamnesis
• skills in administering, scoring and interpreting some commonly used tests
• an experience in providing feedback to a client about his/her test results

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93557,2020,Psychological Science,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. R Zeelenberg', 'prof.dr. HAEM Pecher']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This elective is aimed at psychology students who would like to learn more about psychology as a science. In this course you will learn how psychological questions can be investigated in a methodologically sound way and how scientific literature can be evaluated. Students learn step-by-step how to get from research question to data collection: which research designs are possible, how to avoid confounds and other interfering factors, which conclusions can and cannot be drawn from data and how to write up research in a clear and scientific way. As part of this course a small experiment will be conducted with the Implicit Association Test, which is often used to investigate stereotyping. Literature on this topic will be used to illustrate research design and the results of the experiment will be the basis of a research report. The structure and content of a research report will be discussed in several tutorial meetings. During practical meetings students will practice with Excel and SPSS and learn how to analyse data and create scientific quality graphs. The statistics covered in this course will overlap with BA1 and BA2, but students will get a deeper and more critical understanding of these topics. At the end of the course students can design, execute, analyze, and report scientific research. In addition, they will be able to critically read scientific articles. The grade for the course will be a combination of the grades for the theoretical exam, practical (open book) exam and the written reports. This elective connects to a special bachelor thesis track in which students perform their own research (under supervision) that will be written up in their bachelor’s thesis. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Why do you forget someone’s name? Why do people who are in love get butterflies in their stomach? Are boys better in math than girls? Do you really use only 10% of your brain? Psychologists try to answer such questions, but they do not always agree. How do we distinguish chitchat from fact? And how do we acquire those facts?

In this elective students will attend lectures, tutorial group meetings and practicals to learn skills that are needed to understand and conduct scientific studies. They will conduct a small experiment on stereotyping and practice analyzing the results and writing a scientific report of this experiment.

During this course students can also start a supervised research project that will serve as the basis for their bachelor’s thesis. The research project will continue to run parallel to course periods 4 to 6. This special track of the bachelor’s thesis is not mandatory, but highly recommended for students who take this elective.
By the end of this course students will be able to:

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Door middel van het blok Psychologie van de opleiding Criminologie wordt een inleiding op verschillende perspectieven en thema’s binnen de psychologie gegeven. Daarbij ligt de nadruk op die perspectieven en thema’s die bij uitstek relevant zijn voor de criminologie. Bij de behandeling van deze onderwerpen wordt verwezen naar concrete maatschappelijke problemen en toepassingen in onderzoek. Er wordt in het blok bijvoorbeeld aandacht besteed aan de vraag: hoe kan antisociaal of crimineel gedrag worden verklaard aan de hand van psychologische mechanismen? Daarnaast wordt bekeken hoe psychologische mechanismen andere fenomenen uit de criminologie kunnen verklaren.</body>

column2: • Belangrijke begrippen uit de psychologie en haar stromingen en bijbehorende klassieke onderzoeken omschrijven en uitleggen;
• Antisociaal gedrag, inclusief criminaliteit, verklaren met behulp van psychologische theorieën;
• Criminaliteit gerelateerde onderwerpen en reacties duiden en evalueren met behulp van kennis over de psychologie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, we will explore core psychological principles that affect and shape the behaviour and decisions of actors in organizations. We start with a consideration of what guides independent individual choices and behaviour before gradually exploring how the social context and interdependence with other actors shape these factors. In the final part of the course, we consider settings in which teams work cooperatively to solve problems.

To explore these topics, this course relies on a series of interactive plenary sessions paired with a team project and a survey-based personal reflection assignment. During the plenary sessions we will discuss and analyse selected readings, cases, and research findings as well as engage in a variety of in-class exercises. For the team project, you will be tasked with tackling a practical challenge in individuals’ behaviour. And finally, based on peer feedback, you will reflect on your own behaviour in teams and develop concrete ideas to improve your own functioning in future teams.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The central purpose of this course is to give students insights into how psychological processes shape the behaviour and decisions of individuals acting independently and interdependently in organisations. Specifically, the course covers the following learning goals:

1.    Knowledge acquisition & comprehension: After following this course, students should be able to recall, explain, and discuss core psychological principles and their effects on organizationally relevant behaviours and decisions. These include selected topics in judgment and decision making, persuasion, negotiation, team composition, team processes, and team effectiveness.

2.    Practical application & experimentation: After following this course, students should be able to use the aforementioned theories and research findings to critically analyse and design an intervention to a) affect others’ choice behaviours regarding a societally relevant challenge and b) improve their own teamwork.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92703,2020,Psychometrics: An Introduction,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['CA Onrust, MSc', 'dr. J Jongerling']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Measuring features and skills plays an increasingly important role in everyday life. This course is about measuring in the social sciences. During this course students will discuss the meaning of measurement and how to evaluate the quality of psychological measurements. We emphasize that this course is not only about psychological tests, but includes all kinds of measurements that are used to say something about an underlying construct.

During this course, the most important psychometric attributes to be discussed are reliability and validity. These concepts will be explained according to classical test theory and their importance will be discussed in terms of psychological practice as well as scientific research.
This course will feature the following topics:

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims at introducing students to psychometrics and measurement in psychology and pedagogical & educationa sciences. At the end of the course, students will have gained insights into various psychometric attributes, so they will be able to apply these attributes when working with psychological tests and doing psychological or pedagogical research. Finally, once students have completed this course they will master the SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) skills needed to conduct psychometric data analysis.

Het meten van kenmerken en vaardigheden speelt een grote rol in het dagelijks leven. Tijdens dit blok zal het meten binnen de sociale wetenschappen worden behandeld. De studenten zullen bespreken wat de betekenis is van meten en hoe de kwaliteit van psychologische metingen geëvalueerd moet worden. We benadrukken dat het in dit blok niet alleen om psychologische tests gaat, maar om alle soorten tests die gebruikt worden om iets te kunnen zeggen over een onderliggend construct.

Tijdens dit blok zullen de psychometrische eigenschappen betrouwbaarheid en validiteit centraal staan. Deze concepten zullen behandeld worden aan de hand van de klassieke testtheorie en het belang ervan bediscussieerd in het kader van zowel de pedagogische praktijk als wetenschappelijk onderzoek.
In dit blok komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In deze cursus passeren verschillende vormen van psychopathologie de revue, die ontstaan of aan het licht komen in de kindertijd en adolescentie. Voorbeelden hiervan zijn pervasieve ontwikkelingsstoornissen (bijv. autisme en desintegratie stoornis), aandachtstekort en gedragsstoornissen en de oppositioneel opstandige gedragsstoornis. Om het ontstaan en voortbestaan van zulke stoornissen, evenals de behandelmogelijkheden te kunnen begrijpen, is kennis van de normatieve en de abnormale ontwikkeling nodig. In dit blok integreren we daarom kennis van hersenontwikkeling, ontwikkelingspsychologie, cognitieve psychologie en klinische kinder- en jeugdpsychologie.
Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

International public opinions matter more and more. In order to influence them, nations, but also international organizations such as NGOs or IGOs must develop public relations campaigns in coordination with their policies. Confronted with a growing number of new media that allow anyone to speak their mind globally, the United States is perfecting the concept of Public Diplomacy, in order to ""Tell America's story"". The U.S. is not alone to practice Public Diplomacy; a number of countries are also developing strategic communication campaigns in order to win the global battle of public opinion. In this course, students will explore the importance of public opinions in international relations. Techniques of strategic communication will be discussed and analyzed along with case studies on today's Public Diplomacy. Students will regularly meet practitioners in Public diplomacy. For that reason, a reasonable level of professionalism and flexibility will be required.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Major perspectives on Public Diplomacy and its affiliates like Cultural Diplomacy, Nation Branding and Soft Power;
• Role and importance of public opinions and strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
• Critically review current research on Public Diplomacy;
• Apply theoretical concepts to real-life cases in Public Diplomacy;
• Analyze and reflect on the use and impact of strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
