column3: In dit vak wordt eerst ingegaan op de verschillende rechtsgebieden en rechtsbronnen. Dan wordt het Nederlandse staatsrecht behandeld. Daartoe worden enkele algemene thema's belicht, zoals het juridisch staats- en wetsbegrip en de leerstukken rond bevoegdheid (legaliteitsbeginsel, attributie-delegatie-mandaat).
Bij de behandeling van de Nederlandse Grondwet komen de functie van de staatsorganen en de grondrechten uitgebreid aan bod.

Bij het onderdeel bestuursrecht leert de student kennis maken met en begrip krijgen van de hoofdlijnen van het formele en materiële bestuursrecht en komt de toepassing van de Algemene wet bestuursrecht aan de orde.
Ook de verhouding tussen nationaal en internationaal recht en de plaats van Nederland in de communautaire rechtsorde van de EU worden aan de orde gesteld.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • conflicten en vraagstukken een plaats geven in verschillende rechtsgebieden;
• de verschillende vormen van regelgeving in de nationale rechtsorde benoemen en kunnen aangeven welke organen bevoegd zijn om deze regelgeving tot stand te brengen
• staatsvormingsbeginselen als legaliteit, verantwoording, machtenscheiding en grondrechten aangeven;
• de juridische opbouw van Nederland als gedecentraliseerde eenheidsstaat, democratische rechtsstaat en het overheidsbestuur reproduceren;
• de (wijze van) samenstelling en de functies van parlement, regering en Raad van State benoemen;
• de normen voor bestuurlijk handelen, reguleren en handhaven aangeven en een schending van de algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur herkennen;
• in een gegeven situatie de toepasselijke rechtsbeschermingsprocedures van bezwaar en beroep tegen bestuursorganen selecteren;
• beredeneren waar beginselen en (grond)rechten onderling kunnen botsen;
• aangeven op welke wijze internationaal publiekrecht doorwerkt in de Nederlandse rechtsorde en in verband brengen met de begrippen dualisme en monisme;
• de definities van publiekrechtelijke leerstukken en rechtsbeginselen herkennen;
• wetsartikelen en regels identificeren van publiekrechtelijke rechtsgebieden.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92779,2020,Recht en gezondheidszorg,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. JJ Kempkes', 'mr. KGM Fleetwood Bird']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze Minor maakt u kennis met rechten van verschillende partijen in de gezondheidszorg. U wordt geconfronteerd met de theorie en praktijk van dit rechtsgebied en u zult ervaren dat praktijk en theorie niet steeds naadloos op elkaar aansluiten.

Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.

We hebben te maken met een sterke juridisering van de samenleving als geheel en van het terrein van de gezondheidszorg in het bijzonder. Medisch-technologische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke ontwikkelingen als de vergrijzing en fraude in de zorg, werpen niet alleen vragen en dilemma’s op rond medische, juridische, communicatieve en ethische zaken, maar ook op het gebied van de kostenbeheersing binnen de gezondheidszorg en de daarmee samenhangende toegang tot de zorg.

De Minor staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde.

Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaaleconomische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren. De vraag op de arbeidsmarkt naar gezondheidsrechtelijke expertise is momenteel groot. De Minor voorziet wat dat betreft in deze behoefte.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92784,2020,Recht en gezondheidszorg (deeltijd),Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. KGM Fleetwood Bird']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaal-economische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren.

De gezondheidszorg beslaat inmiddels meer dan 10% van de nationale economie. Het is de sector waar verhoudingsgewijs het meeste geld in om gaat en waarin, ondanks de economische recessie, een spectaculaire groei van de werkgelegenheid is waar te nemen. In de afgelopen tien jaar groeide het aantal banen in de zorg met 385 duizend. Het totaal aantal banen in Nederland nam toe met 515 duizend. Drie kwart van de banengroei in het afgelopen decennium is dus toe te schrijven aan de zorg. De gezondheidszorg is sterk in beweging en juridiseert in toenemende mate. Met gezondheid en gezondheidszorg samenhangende economische, juridische en ethische vraagstukken halen dag in dag uit de voorpagina’s van de dagbladen.

Recht en gezondheidszorg staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde. Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.

Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.

Het gezondheidsrecht bestaat naast eigen wetten en regels die specifiek op de gezondheidszorg van toepassing zijn, ook uit leerstukken van algemeen recht. Allereerst gaan we dan ook in op een aantal algemene rechtsgebieden, zoals het burgerlijke recht, het strafrecht, het bestuursrecht en het internationale recht. Doel is het bekend worden met de aard en de functie van deze rechtsgebieden. Daarnaast staat de betekenis hiervan voor de gezondheidszorg centraal. In sommige gevallen zal dan blijken dat het algemene recht niet voor alles een oplossing heeft, waardoor er toch weer behoefte is aan specifieke regelgeving. Ook de relatie tussen algemeen recht en bijzondere wetgeving is dus een punt van aandacht. Omdat deze Minor toegankelijk is voor studenten van verschillende studierichtingen, zullen afhankelijk van de beschikbare voorkennis, (aspecten) van te bespreken onderwerpen bekend, minder bekend of nog totaal onbekend zijn. Binnen deze Minor is dan ook een van de doelstellingen dat studenten elkaar bevragen, elkaar zaken uitleggen en zo van elkaar leren.

• het opzoeken, interpreteren en toepassen van relevante regelgeving

column1: Dit vak beoogt een verdieping te geven van het onderdeel bestuursprocesrecht van het verplichte vak Bestuursrecht.

De verschillende procedures, te weten de bezwaarschriftprocedure, het beroep bij bestuursorganen en bij de bestuursrechter, de voorlopige voorziening en procedure en het hoger beroep zullen worden behandeld.

Er wordt ingegaan op de posities van de verschillende partijen die betrokken zijn bij een bestuursrechtelijk geschil, te weten de burger, het bestuursorgaan en de beoordelende instantie. Zowel de theorie als de praktijk van het bestuursprocesrecht komt aan de orde.</body>

column1: De doelstelling van het vak Rechtsbescherming tegen de overheid is het aanleren van een kritische houding ten opzichte van de theoretische achtergronden van het geldende bestuursprocesrecht.

Het verwerven van kennis van en inzicht in het geldende bestuursprocesrecht staan centraal. Met de verworven vaardigheden zijn studenten in staat een concrete casus te beoordelen op de procesrechtelijke consequenties en de daarbij behorende strategische keuzes.</body>

MCM Geuskens', 'FG Kwekel, LL.M', 'MH Bahreman', 'mr.dr. C Bouteligier', 'mr.dr. C Elion - Valter', 'mr.dr. S Wahedi', 'prof.dr.mr. W van der Burg']",,"Inhoud

column1: Het overkoepelende thema van dit vak is ‘recht, staat en samenleving’. Onderwerpen die onder meer aan bod zullen komen zijn theorieën van het sociaal contract, democratie en rechtsstaat, grondrechten, de problematiek van multilevel legal orders en global legal pluralism, de grenzen van contractsvrijheid, de belangrijkste ethische theorieën (utilisme, deontologie en deugdenethiek), het debat over legal moralism, strafrechtstheorieën, theorieën van verdelende rechtvaardigheid, juridische beroepsethiek en het debat over universalisme versus relativisme. De relevantie van de vaak abstracte theorieën zal inzichtelijk worden gemaakt door middel van terugkoppeling naar actuele casus.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De algemene doelstelling van het vak valt in twee delen uiteen. Het eerste doel is om de studenten kennis en inzicht te laten verwerven in de normatieve grondslagen en de achtergronden van het recht en de vier grote rechtsgebieden: privaatrecht; staats- en bestuursrecht; strafrecht; internationaal en Europees recht. Het lezen van rechtsfilosofische teksten – moderne én klassieke – is een van de methoden hierbij. Ten behoeve van de toetsing van deze kennis zijn op het tentamen acht korte
kennis- en toepassingsvragen opgenomen (8 x 5 = 40 punten).

Het tweede doel van het vak is om de studenten te trainen in de schriftelijke vaardigheid om filosofisch te reflecteren op het recht en een beargumenteerd normatief standpunt in te nemen. In het onderwijs worden vaardigheden, kennis en inzicht zoveel mogelijk op elkaar betrokken. Een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak vormt de schrijfvaardighedentraining. Deze training vindt plaats in de vorm van vaardighedencolleges en  zelfstudiemodules. Bovendien krijgen studenten tijdens de cursus een take-home schrijfopdracht waarin zij een rechtsfilosofisch advies moeten schrijven (30 punten). Hiernaast dienen zij op het tentamen een essay te schrijven (30 punten).

De rechter moet achterhalen of de verdachte schuldig is aan het tenlastegelegde feit. Dat doet hij door te bekijken of er in het dossier voldoende wettige bewijsmiddelen zitten die hem overtuigen van de schuld van de verdachte. In deze minor wordt ingegaan op wat er allemaal mis kan gaan bij dit proces. Ook wordt ingegaan op een alternatieve, rekenkundige manier van bewijsweging, de zogenoemde Bayesiaanse benadering. Bewijsmiddelen die aan bod komen zijn: getuigenverklaringen, herkenningen en bekentenissen. Verder wordt onder meer ingegaan op leugendetectie, verhoren en tunnelvisie.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Tijdens dit vak worden deelnemers bekend gemaakt met de volgende onderwerpen:
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92065,2020,Recognition in the Visual Arts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['U Hahn, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This class examines recognition within the art world. As in most fields, recognition and renown can lead to various types of artistic success, from economic gain to critical acclaim. However, recognition in the arts is better understood as a social phenomenon, rather than exclusively the consequence of an artistic creator or artwork’s characteristics. Field conventions dictate what is created and ""greatness"" is evaluated according to the standards of time, place, and those professionals credentialed to offer their opinion. In this course, we will take such a sociological perspective in order to arrive at a better understanding of why certain creators are celebrated, while the majority of art and artists are largely unknown. We begin by thinking about what is recognition in the art world and what the different forms of recognition are. Next we discuss what factors contribute to differences in exposure and value. As this course is a research workshop, once we have discussed these questions, we will begin to empirically find answers. Students will conduct a small research project in which they examine recognition in the art world.
Note: It is highly recommended for entry into this course that students have completed the first year course on Methods.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>There are several objectives for this course. First, students gain insight into the sociological examination of the art world and are able to decipher how artistic recognition is formed and what social factors contribute to valuation. Second, students are able to critically read, reflect upon, and synthesize research articles and, ultimately, use them in forming their own research design. Third, students are able to conduct a small research project on recognition in the art world and report on the final work both through written and oral description.</body>

column1: Staatsrecht en bestuursrecht zijn opgebouwd uit rechtsnormen en praktijken die betrekking hebben op verschillende elementen van de uitoefening van openbaar gezag door de overheid. De plaats van de Grondwet en de Algemene wet bestuursrecht verdient uiteraard centrale aandacht, maar daarnaast zijn ook de ongeschreven publiekrechtelijke rechtsnormen – vertrouwensregel, conventies, algemene beginselen van behoorlijk bestuur – van groot belang, en is er de rechtspraak van verschillende hoogste rechters die heeft bijgedragen aan de ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht.

Kwam in blok 2 het rechtsstatelijk kader aan de orde (Rechtsbescherming tegen de overheid), het vak Regeren en besturen zal studenten vertrouwd maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), machtenscheiding, checks and balances, en evenwicht van machten, behoren tot de onderwerpen die in dit vak aan de orde (kunnen) komen.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Regeren en besturen is een staats- en bestuursrechtelijk integratievak. Het beoogt de studenten vertrouwd te maken met problemen die zowel in het staatsrecht als in het bestuursrecht aan de orde zijn. Daartoe zullen ook de historische ontwikkeling van het publiekrecht in Nederland, en de internationale en Europese context waarbinnen dat publiekrecht heden ten dage functioneert, aan de orde kunnen komen.

Het doel van het vak Regeren en besturen is om studenten te vertrouwd te maken met de organisatie van de overheid en de instrumenten die zij kan hanteren. Het verkrijgen van inzicht in vragen van verantwoordelijkheid en verantwoording (accountability), machtenscheiding, en het verkrijgen van de vaardigheid om onderzoek te doen naar - en deel te nemen aan een juridisch debat over – die vragen, behoren tot de leerdoelen van dit vak.</body>

column1: De Research Workshop strekt zich uit over de blokken 2 t/m 4 en is erop gericht de studenten voor te bereiden op en te begeleiden bij het schrijven van hun master thesis. Deze workshop omvat alle fasen van het schrijven van de thesis tot en met het presenteren van het eindresultaat. Studenten kiezen binnen het brede thema van de Research Workshop een eigen onderzoeksonderwerp. Vóór het begin van blok 2 wordt een thesismarkt georganiseerd waarna studenten een keuze maken voor één van de aangeboden Research Workshops en onderzoeksthema’s. Elke Research Workshop kent dezelfde opzet:
- bespreking van literatuur als inleiding op het thema
- individuele sessies met de thesis begeleider
- bespreking van en informatie over mogelijke onderzoeksmethoden
Blok 4: drie plenaire bijeenkomsten en tussentijdse (individuele) sessies met de thesis begeleider
- bespreking van case studies en ander work-in-progress
- presentatie van het thesis onderzoek tijdens Master conferentie juni 2015
- participatie in discussies na afloop van presentaties
Het eindcijfer met het tentamenbriefje voor de Research Workshop wordt gegeven aan het einde van blok 4.
Thema: Reizigers in tijd en ruimte: egodocumenten 1600-1940

De overtuiging dat mensen zelf vorm kunnen geven aan hun persoon en aan de samenleving waarin zij leven, won veld in de 18e eeuw. Mensen konden daarbij leren van voorbeelden en adviezen. In toenemende mate kon men zich daarover informeren in boeken, variërend van (auto)biografieën tot etiquetteboeken, opvoedkundige adviesboeken en, later, romans. Ook de confrontatie met andere volkeren leidde tot een duidelijker definitie van het eigene. Daarover kon wie niet zelf op reis ging geïnformeerd worden door reisverslagen, een steeds populairder genre. Omgekeerd werden Nederlanders en het Nederlandse volk bekeken door buitenlandse ogen. Dat beeld werd eveneens vastgelegd in reisverslagen en reisgidsen, waarvan er steeds meer verschenen dankzij de opkomst   van het moderne toerisme. Dezelfde ontwikkelingen deden zich voor in andere Europese landen. De late 18e eeuw was hierbij een cruciale periode met ook de opkomst van de moderne pedagogie en psychologie, en de groeiende populariteit van vormende kinderliteratuur en adviesboeken. Het is de periode waarin een modern toekomstgericht lineair tijdsbesef ontstond en het daarmee verbonden idee dat de geschiedenis onomkeerbaar is, dat het utopisch denken sterk stimuleerde en waarin de gedachte van een ‘maakbare’ samenleving werd ontwikkeld. Op grond van diverse bronnen - egodocumenten, adviesboeken, biografieën, kinderboeken, reisverslagen en utopieën - zal getracht worden greep  te krijgen op deze en andere mentaal-culturele ontwikkelingen in de overgangsperiode naar de moderniteit.

column1: In this course we look at how religion is variously defined in relation to its content and performance as well as to the ways in which religion is organized and impacts on society. Believers rather than believes are central in our approach, religion being considered to be part of particular historical and cultural contexts and, often, wider global networks. In the lectures Christianity and Islam figure prominently, representing the two largest religious traditions on the globe, but due attention will be paid to other religious traditions and trends, including new religious movements, such as Wicca, but also counter movements such as Pastafarianism. For their assignments and final papers students select and define their own topic in one of following fields:

column2: • Religion and colonization (missionaries, colonial policies, local responses, postcolonial developments)
• Religion, migration and citizenship (diaspora’s, transnational communities, debates and policies concerning (national) identities, including issues of gender)
• Living religion (religion as lifestyle, rituals and beliefs ordering daily life and –possibly- the hereafter)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture.

Ever since the concept of ‘we the people’ was born, with Rousseau and the American and French revolutions, there has been a search for how to represent this sovereign yet elusive entity, ‘the people’, the product of the abolition of fixed social categories like estates. Social relations have now become a matter of contestation and proclamation fueled by association and mobilization. Combined with processes of emancipation, and division of labour, this had led to ever shifting ideas and practices of who represents whom. Parliament, government, the magistrature, labor unions, new social movements, the media, populist politicans all claim to speak in name of the people and to somehow represent either some part, or all of the people.

Democracy, as it unfolds in thought and in practice, both enriches and complicates representation through its claim that ‘the people themselves’ are both willing and able to participate in processes of representation. In its radical form this implies that the people could, and should, represent themselves. As ‘natural’ or traditional representation has vanished, yet ‘the people’ can never be present, the place of power in democracy is ‘empty’, or structurally vacant, and the shaping of both the people and whomever represents them becomes a matter of symbolic practices, which temporarily assign roles and legitimize procedures.

In this course we look at manifestations, conceptualizations, and institutionalizations of the people in forms such as crowds, masses, parliaments, movements, and assemblies. We discuss phenomena like populism, anarchism, communism, and post-politics in their relation to more established forms and ideologies of politics and democracy. We will be reading and discussing authors such as Claude Lefort, Frank Ankersmit, Jodi Dean, Nadia Urbinati, Warren Breckman, Chantal Mouffe, Michel Foucault, and Judith Butler.

column1: World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War  and the recent wars in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences with an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world with a special focus on the medium of comics
Note: The maximum number of participants is 25.

Students learn in what ways a diversity of media and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate  to historical interpretations.

column1: Within a university, teaching and research are combined. At the master level, you will be brought into closer contact with this research. Ultimately, you will have to conduct scholarly research yourself (in your master's thesis). Both for research and in legal practice, certain academic and practical skills are indispensable.

The course in research & writing skills enables you to acquire these skills and to practice. This objective is reached through the writing of papers, making a presentation and through other small-scale seminar forms. The teaching takes place within a small group of students and under the guidance and supervision of one of the researchers. This way you will develop the skills necessary both for legal practice and for academic legal research.</body>

Its focus embraces aspects of business, and data science.

column1: The aim of this course is to offer the foundational considerations for starting your thesis project. Specifically, it focuses on a variety of topics around the first, theory-focused part of your thesis (rather than the empirical part)—including topic choice, research question formulation, framing, and hypothesis development. These topics will be addressed in a series of lectures, building on published work on doing research as well as the experiences and submissions of prior students.

In addition to these subjects, a key aim of the course is to provide students with practical insights with respect to writing academic work, including but not limited to: identifying relevant literature, the issue of plagiarism, writing style, referencing style, reading academic papers, organizing your notes, and using the TOP system.  </body>

4.    Articulating both academic and managerial contributions that the research, if successfully completed, is likely to add.
5.    Outlining a conceptual model to be developed in full in the thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically (and ethically) and the theoretical and social justification for those questions, as well as considerations on how data should be sampled, collected and analyzed, and on how (certain kinds of) inferences and conclusions can be drawn. In this course, students strengthen their research design skills by carefully scrutinizing successful research proposals and designing a research project (proposal) of their own. They formulate scientifically sound research questions, make and justify decisions about literature review, data collection and analysis, data management and research ethics. By presenting and discussing their work in class, they also engage in peer review processes, sharing and receiving suggestions for and from their peers. Seminar discussions pay special attention to the relationship between theory and research; alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods; personal involvement and/or bias; research ethics and data management. Practical constraints that affect research decisions are also considered.

The course is meant to advance and systematize previous knowledge and experience students already have in social scientific research in general. It prepares students for the more specialized methodological courses that follow.

• Design a research project of their own

column1: <body>After the end of this course, students will:

column2: • Have applied the knowledge accumulated in their first year
• Be exposed directly to the different fields’ problems
• Fine-tune their research, programming, and data science skills

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92153,2020,Research Internship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. HJP Delea', 'dr. JC van der Vlies', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Master’s program, students have the opportunity to explore a professional field of interest by means of a Research Internship. Arrangements have been made with around 15-20 national and international archives, museums, research institutes, educational organizations and business companies for research projects which students may select as the subject for their Master’s thesis. Please note that this is not a policy-related internship; it involves an academic research project. The final product may be a publication, an international workshop, website, object analysis or exhibition storyline. This research activity covers 18 working days (5 ECTS). Some internships are linked to the research of a master thesis.

All internships will be announced at the end of term-1 on BlackBoard; there is also an indication whether an internship is linked to a master thesis subject. The internships will also be presented at the Master Thesis Market.

Each student formulates a working plan after consultation with the faculty supervisor and the supervisor of the internship institution. Based on that working plan, an official Agreement Research Internship Master History of Society will be signed by: the student, the supervisor of the institution and the faculty supervisor. The research internship will be completed with a report, written by the student according to the guidelines of the master. The report contains also appendixes with important outcomes and products (written or images of the products). The whole report and internship will be assessed during a final interview with the supervisors. Based on this interview the supervisor of the institution will write a general assessment. The faculty supervisor will assess whether the student
has reached the aims of this internship; there is no grade. For an explanation see the documents on the websitehttp://www.eshcc.eur.nl/english/history/mahs/current/researchinternship/.

• Students can explain how their historical knowledge and skills are transferable to different sectors of employment: business, culture, education, government, research
• Students can reflect on their internship activities in an internship report

column1: This course will provide students with an understanding on the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as the skills to design, conduct and analyze a research study. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research design to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the master thesis.

In this course we provide an overview of methodological principles underlying both qualitative and quantitative methods. We will cover the following topics: reviewing the literature, formulating research questions, research strategies and designs, the nature of qualitative and quantitative research, sampling, common types of data collection methods (interviewing, surveys, and experiments), data analysis, writing, and research ethics.

Note: In continuation of this course, students will do a second course (Research Methodology II) that consists of workshops that they can pick based on what methods they need for their thesis. These workshops will take place from February to May 2021.
Classes will consist of lectures, group discussions, and in-class exercises in which an application of a particular research method is reviewed.

After each session, students will have to do an assignment on Canvas and provide feedback to two randomly assigned and anonymized assignments. In general, deadlines for assignment are at 22h00 on the day of the course; deadline for feedback is at 23h00 on the next working day after the course (exceptions: sessions 2 and 3).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students should be able to:
•    select research methods based on the research questions they want to address
•    collect and analyse data in line with best practices for qualitative research
•    collect and analyse data in line with best practices for quantitative research.

column1: This course consists of a series of workshops on specific qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis methods, namely interviews, experiments, surveys, qualitative coding, and statistical hypothesis testing. In principle, all workshops are offered multiple times, so that students can follow them when at a time that matches with the progress in your thesis project. Students are expected to follow, and actively participate in, at least two of these workshops, depending on the methods they will be using in their thesis research.</body>

column1: This course prepares students for the thesis trajectory that starts in January. The course consists of plenary sessions that are a combination of lecture and workshop. The first two lectures regard general topics about research, research questions and literature review. After these two joint sessions, students select either a qualitative or a quantitative research track for which three/four sessions will follow. In these tracks students are taught a more specialized understanding of either qualitative or quantitative research.
Assessment will have a mixed form and depending on the societal situation teaching will be done online or in a blended form.

column1: At the end of this course, students should be able to:
•    Understand the essence of high quality research and the research phases its consists of.
•    Understand what discriminates different research approaches within either qualitative or quantitative research.
•    Critically compare and evaluate literature streams in order to build an academic argument.
•    Analyze data via the application of the approaches learned in class.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Doel van het leeronderzoek is een eerste kennismaking met de sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoekspraktijk, waarin  studenten groepsgewijs een  empirische cyclus doorlopen van een sociaalwetenschappelijk, hypothese toetsend onderzoek aan de hand van opdrachten . Dit onderzoek begint met een theoretisch zo goed mogelijk beredeneerd voorlopig antwoord op een relevante onderzoeksvraag waarvan vervolgens de houdbaarheid op een methodisch verantwoorde wijze empirisch wordt getoetst. In de conclusies wordt een helder antwoord gegeven op de eerder geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag en hypothesen. Afsluitend wordt gereflecteerd op de beperkingen en opbrengsten van hun onderzoek.

Er wordt geoefend met twee benaderingen: een kwantitatieve, hypothese toetsende benadering en een aanvullende of verdiepende kwalitatieve benadering waarbij dataverzameling en theoretische reflectie elkaar voeden. In elk van beide benaderingen voeren studenten opdrachten uit die uiteindelijk leiden tot het doorlopen van de gehele onderzoekscyclus. De opdrachten vormen de bouwstenen van een onderzoeksverslag dat door de studenten wordt geschreven.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>At the end of this course, students must be able to execute the empirical cycle of a deductive mixed methods research. This means that students must be able to:

column2: • Explain the necessity and relevance of the research;
• Conduct a literature review to provide a theoretical framework for the research;
• Develop hypotheses and turn them into a clear conceptual model;
• Report the findings in a transparent, clear and well-argued manner;
• Draw clear-cut conclusions from the findings and discuss/reflect on them.

J van Dalen', 'dr. O Slivko', 'dr. R Cadario', 'dr. Y Zheng', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts', 'prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij', 'Y Kuper, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Research Project course is about learning how to conduct empirical research to solve business and societal problems. The course provides you both with hands-on experience on the main research methods and on acquiring the knowledge about the principles underlying these methods.

The design of the course covers all stages of the empirical cycle, in which a research problem is identified, relevant literature is explored, a research strategy is designed, qualitative and quantitative data are collected, processed, prepared and analyzed, results of analysis are summarized in writing and presented in various ways in order to communicate the insights effectively and to further critical academic discussion.

During the course, students will work with different kinds of data, both qualitative and quantitative and stemming from different sources. Some data will be self-collected through qualitative interviews, surveys or online experiments. Other data may come from secondary (online) sources and will be downloaded for use in the project. Students will learn how to collect and (statistically) analyze these various kinds of data in order to answer research questions.

This course aims to enable you to approach managerial problems scientifically by learning how to: (1) understand what information is required to answer a question; (2) select the best method for obtaining the required information; (3) learn how to apply the different methods of data collection effectively; (4) apply statistical methods and draw appropriate conclusions from data; (5) engage in precise causal reasoning and understand the limits of data; (6) ethically and accurately communicate information and uncertainty.

Organizations base their strategies on information about the business environment and their main stakeholders such as consumers, industrial buyers, distributors, employees, competitors, suppliers and regulatory bodies. The Research Project course deals with how to collect and analyze this information. The presentation and discussion of results of empirical research are part of everyday life. Not only in discussions about or presentations for business, but also in newspapers about business-related phenomena, and in academic papers. Understanding the way these empirical results have come about and have entered the business, public or academic debate is important in order to be able to judge the validity of the argumentation and the scope of the findings. A thorough comprehension of the many choices that are inherently part of conducting research, the various assumptions that underlie the valid use of research techniques, and the many ways that findings can be presented and communicated, are key ingredients of a critical academic attitude. The Research Project will contribute to these skills.

The Research Project course covers block 5, 6 and 7 of the bachelor curriculum. It is jointly offered by the department of Marketing Management and the department of Technology and Operations Management. It builds on knowledge and skills obtained in Year 1 courses on Philosophy of Science, Marketing Management, Strategic Business Plan, Organizational Behavior, Mathematics and Statistics.

The Research Project course contributes to the overall mission of the school to develop business leaders that can be a force of positive change, by providing the future leaders with the tools and knowledge of research. The course is aimed to make students understand the value of accurate information to solve business problems. It enables students to critically reflect on a business research problem, to evaluate how research findings from within or outside their organization help to (not) solve the problem, and to initiate research in domains where relevant business insight is missing. For the course assignments, a general theme or business or societal problem will be chosen that fits the mission of the School. For example, how to change food habits of consumers towards healthier or more sustainable food choices.

The course research project runs over three blocks in the second year of the bachelor program. Each year, a specific topic or research problem related to the mission of the school will be defined that connects the work in the three blocks. At the end of the course, the students have to integrate learnings and findings from the three blocks in one overall individual report and presentation.

The first block (block 5) concentrates on defining the research problem and learning how to use literature and exploratory research methods to get more and deeper insight into the research problem. Students learn how to formulate research questions, learn about different research designs, setting up research preliminaries, how to collect and summarize literature, how to conduct and report and visualize qualitative and quantitative (secondary) data, how to formulate hypotheses, and how to communicate their problem and findings in an effective way.

The second block (block 6) focuses on survey research methods. A transition is made from exploratory research in the previous block to more confirmatory methods. This block is about quantitative data, data collection by means of questionnaires and analyzing data with inferential statistics. Students learn how to develop valid and reliable measures for the constructs in their research model, learn to design and distribute a proper questionnaire (‘the art of asking questions’), learn about sampling methods, and learn how to use and statistically analyze the collected data to evaluate research hypotheses. Both the knowledge and implied skills of measurement theory and inferential statistical methods will be assessed.

The third block (block 7) puts causality and experimental methods in focus. More specifically, students learn about how to assess causality using the experimental method, learn about the main experimental designs, how to apply experimental or statistical control, and learn how to analyse large data sets using multivariate methods (specifically, regression analysis). Students learn about the use of experiments, the boundaries of correlational analysis, the need for multivariate analysis, the background and application of regression analysis, and the presentation of research results and critical reflection on one's results in group meetings.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of the Research Project course students have the knowledge and practical skills to conduct basic empirical research.
More specifically, students are expected to be able to:

column2: • define a research problem, formulate a research question and develop research propositions, and understand what information is required to answer a question
• learn how to make use of a literature study and exploratory research methods to gather insight into the topic of interest
• learn how to develop interview protocols, conduct interviews, and process and present the results of these interviews

• learn how to download online data from secondary sources or Internet, design stimuli and measures to collect data effectively, set up and conduct (online) surveys, design and conduct (online) surveys and experiments consistent with the research problem under study
• understand, motivate and apply statistical techniques to analyze and report the collected quantitative data, and validly infer from these analyses

• summarize research findings in well-thought out writing, present those findings in various presentation forms, and professionally answer feedback by others or give feedback about the merits and limitations of the research conducted by others.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• interpreting regression results, including p-values and confidence intervals;
• understanding bias using the potential outcomes framework;
• how to use uni- and multivariate regression to make predictions;
• why non-experimental data typically do not yield consistent estimators of causal effects;
• the internal and external validity of experimental results;
• logit average marginal effects and the linear probability model;
• interpretation of the coefficients of dummy variables and interaction terms;
• There will be four plenary lectures: in weeks 1, 2, 3, and 6.

• In the first three weeks, you will complete three online quizzes on Canvas, which will guide you through the learning materials: the first quiz provides information on the topic of this year’s regular assignment: equality of opportunity; the second quiz aims to improve your understanding of econometrics; and the third quiz helps you to brush up your Stata skills. Completion of these online quizzes is compulsory to pass the course and to be allowed to submit your individual homework (see the next item), but they will not count towards your final grade.

• In weeks 1 through 3, students will submit individual homework every week (3 times 5% of your final grade). These three homework problem sets will be graded individually, and form the basis of the regular assignment report that you will write together with your fellow group members (see below). If you get stuck, you may consult your team members but the answers should be your own. Guidelines on how to report your results (e.g. references, tables, figures) will be provided and these guidelines will be strictly enforced by the graders of your individual homework and your group reports.

• Together with your fellow group members, you will hand in the research proposal for the creative assignment in week 5 (10% of your final grade). During the compulsory midterm meeting with an OP team member in week 5, you will discuss this research proposal, as well as any questions you may have about the course materials.

• You will write the reports on the regular (25% of your final grade) and the creative assignment (20% of your final grade) together with your three fellow group members, to be submitted in weeks 5 and 7, respectively. These reports will be assessed at the group (and not the individual) level. There will be inspection sessions for the regular and creative assignment reports, after the lecture of week 6 and in week 9, respectively.

• We encourage all students to meet with their fellow group members (in person, or through Zoom or Skype) at least once a week, for at least two hours, to work on the assignments. Schedule tese meetings at the start of the course. This should enable you to learn from each other.

• During the optional question sessions which, depending on the week, will be held once or twice per week, your group will have the opportunity to discuss with the RP team any questions you may have on that week’s topics. You can submit your questions by email to RP team member [TBD] until 5 PM on the day before a question session, to allow the RP team members to prepare in advance. These question sessions form the core of this course, and we recommend that your group uses this opportunity to get personalized guidance approximately three times throughout the course, depending on need. Try to have all team members attend. Brief answers to the questions that came in will be published in the Q&A-thread on the Canvas discussion board.

• In week 8, there will be a compulsory oral defense of your group work (30% of your final grade, differentiation of the grade between group members is possible). You will be questioned on all of the materials that are offered in this course, and on all aspects of your group work.

column1: You will be required to actively participate from week 1. Doing and understanding research cannot be learned by cramming large amounts of knowledge in a brief period of time, right before an exam. It can only be learned by doing it. This means that for this course, you will be required to actively participate, also in the first weeks. It is therefore advisable to hit the ground running and make a flying start! to compensate for the relatively high workload in the first weeks, there will be no exam so in later weeks you’ll have a bit more time to focus on exams for other courses.

column2: • You will form a group of four students on Canvas using “People/RP group”, before the first lecture. You can discuss group formation issues in the group matchmaking thread on the Canvas discussion board of this course. Students who have not registered for a four-person will be assigned to a group by the RP team. The group member who is the first to register will be the group leader, (s)he will be responsible for registering your group for the midterm meeting, the defense, the question sessions, and for submission of the group assignments.

• Your group leader will register a slot for the midterm meeting in week 5 and the defense in week 8 through Canvas’s calendar function. Only complete groups of four students should register for these meetings. Since attendance is compulsory, please ensure that all group members are available before booking a slot. Registration will be open from the moment that the course is published on Canvas.

• The acceptable file formats when submitting materials are .pdf and .do. The names of files that are submitted as a group should start with the student number of the group leader. The names of the files that you individually submit should start with the student number of the group leader, followed by your own student number.

• Only emails to RP team member [TBD]  will be considered. Do not email other RP team members directly, and also do not send messages through the Canvas direct messaging function, unless you are replying to a message that was sent by the RP team.

column1: Increasingly, employers are looking to hire employees who know how to handle big data files, or who have the skills to use the results from data analyses as inputs for operational or policy advice. Our aim is to help you understand how to apply modern econometric methods, and to help you develop the skills that will allow you to do quantitative empirical research yourself.

In this course, Research Project, you will apply the econometric methods from the course Introductory Econometrics to several data sets. You will write two reports, in the form of research articles, describing your findings. We will refer to the assignments that will help you to write these two reports as the “regular assignment” and the “creative assignment”.

Writing these reports will help you improve your understanding of econometric methods, your Stata skills, and you will gain experience with reporting your findings in a structured manner. Each of the two reports will look like academic articles, following the guidelines that you learned during the course Academic Skills. Taken together, these components of Research Project will provide you with a solid basis for writing your Bachelor’s thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• This year, homework 2 and 3 will be group assignments. Homework 1 will be made individually.

• The groups of four students will be formed after homework 1 has been graded. Students who received a grade below 5.5 for homework 1 will only be allowed to form groups with other students with a grade below 5.5 for homework 1. The purpose of this is to individually activate students early in the course, to limit free-riding. Students who find this course challenging are advised to participate in all question sessions, in which RP team provides individual instruction according to need.

• In week 3, similarly to week 5, there will be a compulsory 15-minute Zoom meeting between an RP team member and two groups of four students. Each student group selects a 15-minute time slot, this is indicated on timetables.eur.nl as ""feedback sessions"".

• To stimulate within-group collaboration in these times of online education, there will be compulsory ""workshops"" in which students will work with their group members in a Zoom breakout room. Attendance during the first 45 minutes is compulsory, failure to attend leads to a points deduction from the final grade. Students are welcome to spend more than 45 minutes in the Zoom breakout room to work on assignments.
• There will be optional question sessions. Attendance is not required, but you are advised to use these sessions from the start of the course to receive personalized instruction.

• Assignment-based re-examination has been replaced by a written (proctored) resit exam. There will be no written exam for students who pass the course without taking the resit exam. If a student scores below a 5.5 for one of the five parts of this course (homework, regular assignment report, creative assignment proposal, creative assignment report, defense), the grade of this part can be upgraded to a 5.5 by scoring a 7 or higher on the resit exam. This can be viewed as a pass/fail exam, the exact grade for the resit exam is irrelevant. If a grade lower than a 5.5 is obtained for two or more parts of this course, scoring a 7 or higher on the resit exam with upgrade the final grade for the whole course to a 5.5. The grade of each of the five parts should be 4.5 or higher to pass the course. Consequently, if the grade of at least one part is below a 4.5, a grade of at least a 7 for the resit is required to pass the course.

• Participation in the resit exam will only be allowed if sufficient demonstrable effort has been made throughout the course, such as submitting most or all required quizzes and assignments on time. This requirement will be subject to the assessment of the course coordinator.

column1: ​The Research Methods in Finance course gives students the opportunity to acquire the statistical and econometric skills needed to work with data, conduct an empirical analysis, interpret and report the results in the context of an academic paper or thesis. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the Master Thesis. Students will attend lectures and workshop sessions, will work with Stata (and Excel) and have to complete an empirical assignment.

For the assignment, students can choose between two tracks: Corporate Finance or Asset Pricing. Otherwise, the two tracks are identical. The skills students train are the same (e.g., processing data, implementing empirical methods using statistical software, and interpreting results), and so is the exam. </body>

Importantly, students should understand the main econometric methods used in finance and apply these to answer research questions.</body>

This course has two major goals. First, it intends to provide students with a greater understanding in three topics in health economics which do not receive much attention in other courses of the master. Second, students will gain more in-depth knowledge by applying the econometric tools taught in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics to data on each of the three topics.

The emphasis of the course is on the research angle. For each topic, a) introductory lectures will be given to set the scene; b) next, students have to read papers, and solve an empirical group assignment which will consequently be discussed in class; and c) finally, students have to do an individual econometric analysis based on real-life datasets.

column2: • the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model and unhealthy habits

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The major aim of this course is to acquire and apply economic and econometric tools to health issues. After this course, students should have a greater understanding of the three aforementioned topics in health economics, and have more hands-on experience with the tools acquired in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics. More exactly, students should be able to:

column2: • define the relations between ageing populations and health care expenditures
• use the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model to evaluate public health policy in the domain of unhealthy habits
• understand the important linkages between health, health insurance and the organization of the labour market, and retirement behaviour

column1: Students should also be able to:

column2: • combine data, economic theory and econometric tools to analyze data on one of the three topics
• present research findings on each of the 3 aforementioned topics

column1: <body>During the research traineeship in the first year of the Research master's programme, students participate in one of the Faculty's research projects or in an external research project which is led by a Faculty member or in which a Faculty Member is involved as an advisor. The traineeship results in (a substantial contribution to) a research paper or research report and familiarizes students with some of the most vital research activities: developing a research project, writing a research proposal, doing the actual research and data analysis, and presenting research findings in the form of a research paper or research report and an oral presentation. In principle, the research subject should fit within the fields that are covered in the research master's and it should fit within the Faculty's current research projects and research interests. In order to guarantee the suitability and quality of the supervision and the traineeship, a concise research traineeship proposal should be submitted to the Programme directors who need to approve of the chosen subject and content of the traineeship before the start of the traineeship. A research traineeship includes at least the following components:

column2: • Contribution to research report or research paper
• Attendance and active participation in presentations by fellow students.

column1: We will study selected aspects of methodology (what is research?) and empirical research methods (how do we collect and analyze data?). ​During the course, we will discuss previous empirical findings and methodological tools available in our field. Students will have the chance to develop a research proposal to understand the relationship between the problem statement, the analysis of the data, and the concluding answer to the research question. The course will provide the discussion space to explore setting up a research project which, eventually, can become the actual MA thesis. At the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to apply the empirical methods of the discipline to develop a coherent and feasible research proposal.

<body>This research workshop introduces students to the main issues concerned with doing cross-national comparative research in communication and media, while it also offers them advanced training in writing a comprehensive literature review on a research topic of their own choosing. It is a practical course that introduces students to a number of important steps in the choices to make when carrying out cross-national and/or comparative research.</body>

• Conduct a systematic analysis and critical evaluation of the secondary literature on selected issues or topics in the field of communication and media;
• Write a clear and balanced literature review as a team, presenting the state of knowledge regarding their chosen cross-national and comparative research topic;
• Work collaboratively on small and large international teams while profiting from and reflecting on the diverse input this entails;

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide students an understanding of management in the cultural sector. The starting point of view is that cultural organizations such as museums, venues, musical societies, theatre companies, and other creative enterprises possess particular characteristics from an organizational point-of- view that influence the way they operate. Cultural/arts management has developed as a full-fledged discipline. Cultural organizations increasingly need to develop management strategies to realize their objectives, paying attention to their potential visitors-audiences-users, and to the financial constraints that may hinder their activities. The cases selected by the students will be used to study and illustrate the impact that strategic management can have on the performance of cultural institutions. Students will have to apply the theoretical framework to cultural organizations in order to see how theory translates into reality.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This research workshop will familiarize students with the management of cultural organizations by case study research methods. They learn to connect theory to practice by conducting their own small research project about an existing cultural organization.</body>

column1: From Hobbiton to Graceland to 221b Baker Street, media- and cultural tourism – visiting places in the wake of popular culture & heritage – is a growing industry. While connected to traditional forms of sightseeing, media- and cultural tourism raises different questions about the relationship between the mass media, its audiences, and physical places. What are tourists looking for? How are these attractions marketed and managed? And what about the locals, who see their home suddenly becoming a ‘fictional’ location swarming with tourists? What does the increased prominence of this kind of tourism say about the relationship between imagination and reality in an era characterized by an increasing omnipresence of the media and global mobility? These are the sort of questions asked in this course. Students will explore different aspects of media- and cultural tourism, from its origins and history, its connection to other parts of the tourism industry, its relationships to audience- and fan-practices, managerial aspects, and tourist experiences in order to foster a sophisticated understanding of this multifaceted phenomenon. Starting from this, students will create their own small research project on an aspect of media- or cultural tourism that interests them. Students will use research techniques and methodology from cultural studies and qualitative sociology, hence it is advised to be familiar with these before partaking the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This research workshop will introduce students to the key issues in media- and cultural tourism: that is, tourism inspired by (popular) media, such as films, TV-series, music, literature and video-games. Students will be able to identify the current themes and challenges to orient themselves within the ongoing academic debates surrounding media- and cultural tourism. Students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in academic publications. Students will extend this knowledge through conducting a small-scale qualitative research through hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data, developing a research design and reporting on their findings.

column1: The research clinic prepares the student for writing the thesis proposal. The clinic will provide insights into types of research questions and their requirements. It will provide an overview of research strategies and the appropriateness of these related to various types of research questions. Furthermore, various forms of data collection and analysis techniques – related to the research strategy – are discussed. As students follow a ‘master in management’ students will learn how to discuss and think about the managerial relevance of their research question.

To properly discuss and learn about types of data collection and data analysis the research clinic is organized in various tracks running in parallel for different groups of students depending on their choice of a thesis topic and the exact research question. Students will participate in one of the following tracks:

column2: • Track for students who want to write their thesis in Finance
• Track for students who want to conduct a quantitative analysis
• Track for students who want to conduct a qualitative analysis

column1: These tracks provide hands-on exercises to help students to collect their data adequately and conduct their analysis in the thesis autonomously. The thesis proposal is conditional for the thesis.

Students will participate in one of the following tracks:

column2: • Track for students who want to write their thesis in Finance
• Track for students who want to conduct a quantitative analysis
• Track for students who want to conduct a qualitative analysis

column1: These tracks provide hands-on exercises to help students to collect their data adequately and conduct their analysis in the thesis autonomously. The thesis proposal is conditional for the thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The research fundamentals course is designed to support the individual master thesis project. The course focuses on the study of the various thesis research methodologies that are available for conducting research in Innovation Management. These include qualitative research (case studies or grounded theory), surveys and archival data analyses, and experiments.

The course main components are the Research Fundamentals I & II courses. Research Fundamentals I comprises a set of introductory lectures. The goal of these lectures is to discuss the basic concepts of research and for students to get a better understanding of how to design a research project. Students will work on topics that go from developing a research question to making a preliminary selection of a research method for their study. Research Fundamentals II comprises group sessions and workshops, specific to a certain research method. These sessions will provide students with in-depth knowledge and skills that can be applied on their own thesis.

This course works according to the flipped classroom principle, which means that the student needs to prepare before class following the suggested material. The lectures are used for interactive feedback, gamification, and in-class discussion, to deepen the student’s knowledge of the methodology and to provide specific feedback on her/his work. Meanwhile, through the assignments, the student will work on the method section for the thesis, integrating what has been learnt through the course.

column1: •    Are able to make the distinction between qualitative and quantitative methodologies in studies of Innovation Management.

•    Are able to make a choice between qualitative and quantitative analysis in accordance with the research question of their thesis.
•    Are able to use the selected methodology for answering the research question of their thesis.
•    Are able to plan and execute the actions to complete a thesis in the area of Innovation Management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The design of a (digital) behavioral intervention and its evaluation go hand in hand. The results of one affect the other, and vice versa. Therefore, for the success of any type of behavioral intervention it is crucial to have a clear view of the key aspects to evaluate, and how to evaluate them already from the very start of the design process. Questions like “What are the key aspects that define the success of an intervention?”, “How do we evaluate them?”, “What sources of information are crucial for the overall evaluation of (digital) behavior change intervention (DBCI)?” “What is the trade-off between scientific optimality and practical feasibility in the formulation of a suitable experimental design for the impact evaluation of a DBCI?”, “What are the issues to carefully evaluate when embarking in an DBCI project, such as ethical and practical aspects?”, “What type of outcomes can be considered and how do you operationalize them?”, will be answered through a selected list of readings, plenary lectures, assignments, and in-class discussions.

The course will give a broad overview of research designs and approaches used in (digital) behavior change research, including critical appraisal techniques, qualitative, quantitative and mixed-methods research methods. The focus is on how to address dilemmas in everyday research practice with a special attention on feasibility, validity, and reproducibility of the different methods. Students are stimulated to develop 1) an understanding of the research process involved in the evaluation of DBCIs along all phases of design and implementation, and 2) a creative, yet pragmatic scientific thinking. The course will prepare students with the knowledge and skills to carry out research projects, such as the MSc thesis.

The overarching goal of this course is to provide the students with a set of research principles, guidelines, tools, and skills necessary to design an empirical research project, but also paving the ground for a critical understanding of methodological, ethical and pragmatic issues in the development and implementation of (digital) behavior change interventions. The workshop aims to introduce the fundamental ingredients of the research process for behavior change interventions, which are not exclusive to the “digital” context but are transversal to any type of complex behavioral intervention.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will be able to...

column2: • Conceptualize testable research questions relevant to (digital) behavior change and explain the background rationale
• Select appropriate methods and research designs for the evaluation of a DBCI along all phases of development and implementation
• Critically evaluate methodological, ethical and pragmatic aspects involved in the evaluation of a DBCI, in the light of context, users, type of technology and content of the DBCI
• Develop a detailed (mock) research protocol for the evaluation of a DBCI for a target group of users.

column1: This summer school course covers major and foundational topics research on social entrepreneurship and social enterprise (SE). The objective of the course are, (1) to familiarize you with some of the core concepts and primary theoretical underpinnings of research on social entrepreneurship; (2) to help you gain a stronger understanding of, and think critically about, the SE domain, including its research requirements and methods for publishing scholarly research in management and organizational studies; and, (3) to provide a forum where you can further develop your thinking and writing skills as a social entrepreneurship scholar.

The primary purpose of the course is to develop your ability to do scholarly research in this area. Therefore, the course should help you to (1) develop, refining, and present your own research ideas; (2) gain a better understanding of the research and publication processes; and (3) empower you to find your own voice.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will first be introduced in the field of cultural tourism, as an increasingly important subfield or niche of tourism in general. Cultural tourism has a long history, with roots reaching back to the Grand Tour in the 18th Century. Since then cultural tourism has been booming. Due in part to globalisation and postmodernism the character of concepts such as 'culture' and 'local identity' has become more fluid, with changing meanings to different groups in society. The ways in which tourism, visual culture and local identity are intertwining is the central theme and starting point of this research seminar. Next to that, several important qualitative research methodologies will be touched upon, familiarizing students with doing qualitative research towards cultural tourism by means of content analysis, participant observation, in-depth interviewing and ‘netnography’, amongst others. After this, students will be sent out into the field, explore how issues related to cultural tourism are acquiring significance in practice and engage hands-on in applying their methodological as well as theoretical knowledge in this field to engage with a small-scale empirical research project in line with their own interests.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will be made familiar with a wide range of qualitative research methods, which will prepare them for conducting an independent research towards the way(s) in which place, culture and tourism intertwine and intersect in empirical reality. In order to do so, students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of cultural tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Following this, students will apply their knowledge in a small-scale qualitative research, developing a research design and acquiring hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data in addition to presenting findings amidst peers.

column1: Responsible Business Leadership (BT2101) is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management and examines business in an increasingly global world, where organizations operate in a complex natural, social and economic environment. Corporations are expected to act responsibly toward various stakeholders, such as governments, competitors, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), shareholders, suppliers and employees, to do the morally right thing, and to foster sustainable development. These high expectations can be challenging, yet they also create business opportunities. In particular, business plays a pivotal role in realizing the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals by creating not only economic value, but also ecological and social value.

Responsible Business Leadership is meant to be a provocative course, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change in the world by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems, such as inequality, corruption and climate change. While business is often a part of these problems, we examine how it can also be part of the solution. You are therefore encouraged to think about how business can create value not just specifically for shareholders, but also for other stakeholders, including society in general.

After introducing the Sustainable Development Goals as an overarching framework in Lecture 1, we will give in Lecture 2 and 3 a broad introduction to the central concepts of Sustainability—which is key in Workshop 1—and Responsibility. Lectures 4 and 5, which are central to Workshop 2, subsequently examine how sustainability and responsibility allow companies to go beyond business-as-usual in more specific domains such as strategy and entrepreneurship, as well as how this helps to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. Lecture 6 introduces the third central concept of this course, Ethics, to which Workshop 3 will subsequently be devoted.

The three workshops that are intermixed with these six lectures focus, respectively, on developing your vision on sustainability and your authentic leadership, formulating a proposal for a corporate responsibility strategy and discussing managerial moral dilemmas with other students. These workshops thus make the course material more directly relevant to you, by linking it to your personal development and awareness of sustainable challenges.
To help you further engage with the course material, supplementary video materials and animations will be made available. Finally, after six lectures, the written test will be organized.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course, you will be able to:
• Explain the roles that companies play in the creation of and finding solutions for local and global sustainability issues, including corruption, climate change and inequality.

• Apply concepts and theories relevant to how organizations can and should contribute to solving these issues through the way they organize themselves internally and the way they interact with external stakeholders.
• Explain your own standpoint on how companies can contribute to solving these sustainability issues.
• Create a plan on how to contribute to solving these issues
